Welcome to my Summer 2021 TA application

Dear Dr. Todd Fenton

Chair, Department of Anthropology Michigan State University

I am writing to express my interest in the summer positions the Department of Anthropology is offering. After reviewing the course offer, I realized I am very well suited for assuming a leading role with ANP 330 and ANP 201 classes. As well, I have the proven capacity to carry an assistant position with the ANP 200 class.

I am currently cursing the third year of the MSU Ph.D. anthropology program. Still, I already have a Master in Cultural Studies and experience designing, teaching, and administering higher education courses. I find that the possibility of conducting an online course will give me valuable experience for my professional development. I also believe my expertise over nation-building, ethnicity, culture, and cultural difference will benefit the students.

I am prioritizing ANP 330 over the other interests of mine. The reason is I have never given any class exclusively focus on race, ethnicity, and nation-building. I know having the chance to have a leading role in that class could help my career in the future. My second choice is ANP 201, a class I enjoyed and could lead last year for the first time. Finally, I am also interested in ANP 200, a course I know very well after two successful assistantships and another one more in the making.

In the following sections of the webpage, you will find a better description of my interest in the subjects I mentioned. In the last section, you will find an account of the classes I have taken at MSU, my TA appointments, and the fellowships I have been awarded as an MSU student.

ANP 330 Race, Ethnicity and Nation

ANP 330 is a course exploring the anthropological discussions surrounding the formation of collective identity and difference. Race, ethnicity, and nation are cultural constructs, but like any other construct, they have powerful material effects on people's everyday lives. I look forward to gaining relevant teaching experience leading such an essential course for the proper understanding of culture, and the current socio-political conjuncture of almost every corner of the world.

Courses like ANP 410, ANP 810, ANP 811, ANP 830, and ANP 840, give me an excellent background for a successful engagement with the course's material and the student's doubts. The knowledge I acquired from my master's degree in Cultural studies, especially regarding Stuart Hall's scholarship on blackness and racism, should also be productive for my commitment to the course material. But my most distinctive asset to lead ANP 330 is my experience with Latin American decolonial theory (LADC). My contact with LADC has shown me how critical race ideologies were for the modern-state formation in Latin America. I firmly believe my ability to bridge state and nation-building with race and ethnicity makes me a strong candidate to lead ANP 330.

ANP 201 Introduction to Cultural Anthropology

omaiga

ANP 200 Navigating Another Culture
